questions.question: Which viral organism is most commonly associated with myocarditis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Coxsackievirus Explanation: Coxsackievirus is a common cause of viral myocarditis, especially in young adults. Other virus includes the Herpes virus and Trichinella Spirali (parasitic). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 560

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the vegetation found in Infective Endocarditis compared to other conditions? platelets. inflammatory cells, and microorganisms. vegetations composed mainly of fibrin and platelets. micro-organisms.

options.A: Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are typically small, friable, sterile and composed of fibrin, and
options.B: Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin,
options.C: Nonbacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (NBTE) commonly presents with small, non-sterile
options.D: Libman-Sacks Endocarditis is characterised by tiny, marantic vegetations consisting of fibrin and

questions.explanation: of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms. Correct answer : B) Vegetations in Infective Endocarditis are large, verrucous, and primarily consist of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms. Explanation: Rheumatic heart disease Infective Endocarditis Non-bacterial Thrombotic Endocarditis (Option C) Libman-Sacks Endocarditis (Option D) Small and warty Large and bulky (Option B) (Option A ruled out) Small and friable Medium sized Along lines of closure Upper surface of cusps Along lines of closure Both surface of valves (M/C-lower surface) Sterile Non- sterile Sterile Sterile Emboli - Emboli +/- Emboli +++ Emboli - Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 560

questions.question: Which of the following findings is most likely present in the myocardial biopsy of a Rheumatic Heart disease patient?

options.B: Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart
options.C: Calcific nodules on the valve leaflets
options.D: Disruption of the endothelial lining of blood vessels

questions.explanation: the heart Correct answer: B) Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, Anitschkow cells and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart Explanation Areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, plump macrophages and fibroblasts in all layers of the heart are the characteristic features of Rheumatic Heart Disease. Aschoff bodies , characterized by areas of lymphocytic infiltrates, plump macrophages (Anitschkow cells) , and fibroblasts, are commonly found in all layers of the heart (maximum in myocardium) of patients with Rheumatic Heart Disease. These structures are indicative of the inflammatory response associated with acute rheumatic fever. Anitschkow cells: They display abundant cytoplasm and central round to ovoid nuclei, occasionally binucleate, with chromatin condensed into a central, thin, wavy ribbon, presenting two distinct morphological patterns as: Caterpillar chromatin pattern "Owl eye" appearance Anitschkow cells, also known as caterpillar cells, are plump macrophages with an elongated, wavy nucleus. They are characteristic histological features found in Aschoff bodies. These cells play a role in the inflammatory response within the myocardium during acute rheumatic fever. Fibrous thickening of the endocardium (Option A): Seen in chronic RHD , not acute RHD. Calcific nodules on valve leaflets (Option C): Occur in senile aortic stenosis (age-related degeneration). Disruption of the endothelial lining of blood vessels (Option D): Found in vasculitis (e.g., Kawasaki disease, PAN) , not RHD. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 564

questions.question: Which of the following is not a major criterion according to Jones Criteria for Rheumatic Heart Disease?
questions.explanation: Correct answer : D) Fever Explanation: Jones Criteria: Major Criteria Minor Criteria Carditis (Option B) Polyarthritis (Option A) Chorea (Sydenham’s) Subcutaneous nodules (Option C) Erythema marginatum Clinical Fever Polyarthralgia Prolonged PR interval Lab Increased ESR Increased CRP Minor criteria present in previous episodes or evidence of previous rheumatic fever The presence of either two major criteria or one major criterion plus two minor criteria, along with evidence of a preceding streptococcal infection, supports the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever according to the Jones Criteria. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 561

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug abuse, presenting with fever, malaise, and a new-onset heart murmur, reports recent injection site infections. On examination, there are multiple healing scars on the upper extremities, and a grade III/VI holosystolic murmur is auscultated at the left sternal border. His temperature is 38.5°C, heart rate is 110 bpm. Which criterion amongst the following is a major criterion for the condition diagnosed?

options.A: Fever of unknown origin lasting more than 7 days
options.C: Predisposing cardiac condition such as a prosthetic heart valve
options.D: Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures

questions.explanation: blood cultures Correct answer: D) Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures Explanation: The diagnosis in a 45-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug abuse, presenting with fever, malaise, and a new-onset heart murmur is Infective Endocarditis. The Duke’s Criteria for diagnosing Infective Endocarditis include major criteria such as positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures (e.g., Streptococcus viridans, Staphylococcus aureus), echocardiographic evidence of endocardial involvement (vegetations or abscesses), and the presence of a new valvular regurgitation. Additionally, minor criteria include fever, predisposing cardiac conditions, vascular phenomena, immunological phenomena, and microbiological evidence not meeting major criteria. Duke’s Criteria: Major Criteria Minor Criteria Positive blood cultures for typical microorganisms persistently isolated from blood cultures (2 cultures > 12 hrs apart, single positive culture for Coxiella) Predisposing cardiac conditions such as a prosthetic heart valve (Option C), IV drug abuse (Option B) Evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiography (vegetations or abscesses) Fever ( ≥ 38.0°C) (Option A) New valvular regurgitation Vascular phenomena (e.g., emboli, Janeway lesions) Immunological phenomena (e.g., glomerulonephritis, Osler's nodes) Microbiological evidence not meeting major criteria (e.g., positive blood culture but not persistently positive) For diagnosis, either of the following should be present: 2 major criteria OR 1 major criteria and 3 minor criteria OR 5 minor criteria Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 563

questions.question: Which of the following genes is most commonly associated with inherited forms of dilated cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) TTN gene Explanation: TTN gene mutation, which is specific to inherited dilated cardiomyopathy is the correct option. It encodes for nuclear lamina proteins and can disrupt the structure and function of the heart, leading to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy. Truncation mutations in TTN, a gene that encodes titin (the largest protein expressed in humans), may account for approximately 10% to 20% of all cases of DCM. In the genetic forms of DCM, autosomal dominant inheritance is the predominant pattern. Histologic appearance of the enlarged, bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei (likened to “ Ninja stars ”) that are seen in greater numbers in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy caused by titin-truncating mutations. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 569

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath following the news of a family member's serious illness. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, and cardiac biomarkers are elevated. Coronary angiography reveals no significant coronary artery disease. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Excessive release of catecholamines. Explanation : Excessive release of catecholamines is the most likely underlying mechanism for the development of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy in this patient. Emotional or physical stress, such as the news of a family member's serious illness, can trigger a surge of catecholamines (e.g., adrenaline and noradrenaline). Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is an entity characterised by left ventricular contractile dysfunction after extreme psychological stress (thus also called broken heart syndrome) Maximum catecholamine receptors are present in the left ventricle, leading to LV dilation. Affected myocardium may be stunned or show contraction band necrosis, which can eventually progress to DCM. The left ventricular apex is most often affected, leading to “apical ballooning” that resembles a takotsubo, Japanese for “fishing pot for trapping octopus”. The mechanism of catecholamine cardiotoxicity likely relates either to direct myocyte toxicity due to calcium overload or to focal vasoconstriction in the coronary arterial macro- or microcirculation in the face of an increased heart rate. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 570

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterised by transient left ventricular dysfunction, often triggered by emotional or physical stress, presenting with symptoms mimicking acute coronary syndrome but with normal coronary arteries on angiography?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (TCM) Explanation: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy also known as BROKEN HEART SYNDROME following extreme psychological stress. The left ventricle is dilated with apical ballooning resembling a JAPANESE POT named TAKOTSUBO used for catching Octopus. The patient presents with symptoms resembling acute coronary syndrome such as chest pain. Ventriculography typically shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with preserved basal contractility. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 575

questions.question: A 22-year-old man presents to his cardiologist with complaints of exertional chest pain and shortness of breath. His family history is significant for the sudden cardiac death of his brother at the age of 28. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic murmur and irregular heart sounds. Which of the following genes is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Beta-myosin heavy chain Explanation: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): It is a common (1 in 500 prevalence) clinically heterogeneous genetic disorder characterized by myocardial hypertrophy , poorly compliant left ventricular myocardium leading to abnormal diastolic filling , and (in about one-third of cases) intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction. It is the leading cause of left ventricular hypertrophy unexplained by other clinical or pathologic causes. It is a leading cause of sudden death in the young and is an important cause of heart failure. Causes: HCM is most commonly caused by mutations in any one of several genes that encode sarcomeric proteins. There are more than 400 different known mutations in nine different genes, most being missense mutations. Mutations causing HCM are found most commonly in the genes encoding myosin-binding protein C (MYBP-C) or β -myosin heavy chain ( β -MHC/MYH7) , followed by the genes coding for cardiac TnI, TnT (Option C), and α -tropomyosin (Option D) ; overall, these account for 70% to 80% of all cases. Titin (Option A) : Titin mutations are seen in dilated cardiomyopathy (20% of the cases). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 572

questions.question: A 19-year-old boy collapsed during a football game and was brought dead to the hospital. Suspecting a heart condition, a biopsy was done, which showed asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the following histological findings will not be seen in this condition?

options.C: Fibrotic narrowing of small intramural arteries

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Ninja star nuclei Explanation: The clinical presentation of a young male who collapsed and died (sudden cardiac death) with a biopsy showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Grossly it forms a banana-shaped LV Cavity. Histology of HCM includes: Myofibre Hypertrophy (Option A) Myofibre Disarray (Option B) Fibrotic narrowing of intramural arteries (Option C) . Ninja star nuclei are seen in Dilated Cardiomyopathy. The images below show the gross and histological features of HCM. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 571,573

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause for restrictive cardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Alcohol Explanation: Alcohol is not a cause of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Rather, it is a cause of dilated cardiomyopathy. CAUSES OF RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY Amyloidosis (Option B) Hemochromatosis (Option A) Radiation Scleroderma Tropical endomyocardial fibrosis Hypereosinophilic syndrome (Löffler’s endocarditis) Sarcoidosis (Option C) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 574 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page 1968

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presents with progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion and bilateral lower limb swelling for the past few months. She reports a history of recurrent fevers and weight loss over the past year. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, ascites, and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Echocardiography reveals restrictive filling patterns with apical obliteration and thickened endocardium. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Endomyocardial fibrosis Explanation Congestive heart failure (dominant right-sided symptoms) and echo findings are highly suggestive of endomyocardial fibrosis, a form of restrictive cardiomyopathy. Endomyocardial fibrosis: It is principally a disease of children and young adults in Africa and other tropical areas. It is characterized by fibrosis of the ventricular endocardium and subendocardium that extends from the apex upward , often eventually involving the tricuspid and mitral valves. The fibrous tissue markedly diminishes the volume and compliance of affected chambers, causing a restrictive functional defect. Ventricular mural thrombi sometimes develop, and indeed much of the endocardial fibrosis may result from thrombus organization. Endomyocardial fibrosis is linked to nutritional deficiencies and/or inflammation related to parasitic infections (e.g., hypereosinophilia). Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 574

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis based on the image given below? It is a stained specimen of endomyocardial tissue.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Cardiac amyloidosis Explanation: The image shows characteristic extracellular deposition of amorphous material with apple-green birefringence under polarized light on Congo red staining , confirming the diagnosis of Amyloidosis It is the most common cause of Restrictive Cardiomyopathy. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 574, 575

questions.question: Identify the true statements regarding atrial myxoma. 1) It is the most common primary tumor of the heart in adults. 2) It is a malignant neoplasm. 3) It is associated with mutations in the GNAS1 gene. 4) 90% of these tumors arise from ventricles. 5) Histologically, it contains lepidic cells
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 1,3,5. Explanation: Atrial myxoma: The most Common Benign Tumor Of the Heart (Statement 1) Site- Most Commonly Seen In Left Atria Gross Appearance- Gelatinous Histologically- Stellate Or Lepidic Cells Seen (Statement 5) It is associated with mutations in the GNAS1 gene. (Statement 3) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 579

questions.question: A 6-month-old infant presents with cyanosis and respiratory distress. Physical examination reveals a murmur and a palpable liver edge. Echocardiography demonstrates multiple intracardiac masses located primarily in the ventricular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Rhabdomyoma Explanation: RHABDOMYOMA Most common benign tumor in children Most commonly found in ventricles and are multiple 50% are associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Microscopy shows spider cells showing vacuolated cytoplasm comprised of glycogen. These are positive for PAS Stain. The image below shows spider cells. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 579,580

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents with palpitations and dizziness during a soccer match. He is diagnosed with ARVC (Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy). Which of the following statements about this condition is true? Statement 1 - It is an autosomal recessive disorder Statement 2 - Associated with NAXOS syndrome Statement 3 - Marked by fatty infiltration and focal fibrosis within the ventricle Statement 4 - It involves mutation in Plakoglobin
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2, 3, 4 Explanation: Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC) is an autosomal dominant disorder. (Statement 1 ruled out) The right ventricular wall is markedly thinned due to myocyte loss, with extensive fatty infiltration and focal fibrosis (Statement 3) . It presents with right-sided heart failure and arrhythmias, which can lead to sudden cardiac death. Mutations in genes encoding, Desmosomal junctional proteins at the intercalated disk (e.g., plakoglobin) (Statement 4) Proteins that interact with the desmosome (e.g., the intermediate filament desmin). Associated with NAXOS syndrome (Statement 2) , it includes: Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Cardiomyopathy (ARVC) Woolly hair Palmo-plantar keratoderma Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page 572.
